byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick contributed reporting from Tunis, and Heba Afify from Cairo.

abstract: Renowned Islamic thinker Rachid al-Ghannouchi, founder of Tunisia's Islamist party, believes that democracy and Islam can coexist in Tunisia, and his ideas may be tested if his party succeeds in coming elections.
snippet: Democracy and Islam can coexist in Tunisia, Rachid al-Ghannouchi believes, and his ideas may be tested if his party succeeds in Sunday’s voting.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

lead_paragraph: Democracy and Islam can coexist in Tunisia, Rachid al-Ghannouchi believes, and his ideas may be tested if his party succeeds in Sunday’s voting.

headline.main: Islamist Imagines a Democratic Future for Tunisia
headline.print_headline: A Veteran Islamist Imagines a Democratic Future for the New Tunisia
headline.seo: Rachid al-Ghannouchi Imagines Democratic Future for Tunisia
